For 2026. Again, we are trying to predict a year ahead what the budget will be in terms of consultancy projects delivered and other spend.
What Mr. Gannon is actually saying that if the CRU makes a surplus it is not really intended.
No, but also that it is carried through to serve that purpose into the next year. It does not go anywhere. It is brought back in to the next year.
We are not a profit-making organisation. We are not for profit. We are just set up by statute.
Yes. I just asked the question.
One of the biggest issues I get complaints about is the delays in people getting connections. Often, there is an EBS issue.

However, it can also involve Uisce Éireann in particular. What is the regulator doing about it? Uisce Éireann is way behind. How much of the regulator's activity is based on water quality as opposed to water quantity? In recent years, I have heard that water quality is getting substantial attention as opposed to the quantity of water. We want both. Let us start on that basis. How does the regulator distinguish between those two areas in terms of its workload? New houses are built, mortgages are ready and everything is done, the ESB is there but Irish Water says the sewage treatment plant is full. Based on what I hear as a TD, the regulator could not possibly be satisfied with how Uisce Éireann is doing its work in this regard.
To clarify, we do not have a role in water quality. That is the role of the EPA as the environmental regulator.
Could Dr. Kavanagh start again? When it comes to water, there is another regulator looking after quality while the commission is connected with-----
We are the economic regulator for Uisce Éireann.
I now understand why we have 100 regulators. They are both monitoring the same litre of water but relating to different aspects.

We set the framework by which Uisce Éireann receives funding to invest in the infrastructure that would serve water quality and quantity. The EPA examines Uisce Éireann's performance against the parameters, so we are the economic regulator.
Who examines the quantity of water?

As the economic regulator, Uisce Éireann will come to us with its business plan. Uisce Éireann has a different model. It starts with the Minister in terms of the policy statement. It is approved by the Minister with a strategic funding plan and then it comes to us as a business plan for the forthcoming five years. We review that in terms of what it is proposing to spend and we set a number of outputs and outcomes in terms of how we monitor kilometres of network and pumping stations - all of the infrastructure Uisce Éireann has to deliver on both the water side and the wastewater side.
Is that not in the plan that comes to the regulator for approval?

We have just published our draft determination for the next period. We have done a deep dive in terms of the types of projects Uisce Éireann is proposing to see whether they are suitable and fit for purpose and whether they are delivering at an efficient cost so we challenge Uisce Éireann in terms of what it is proposing. We will then monitor that over the course of RC3 to see what it is delivering. One of the things we would have found in the last period was that Uisce Éireann was doing very well in terms of water and we expressed some concern on the wastewater side that it was not delivering as quickly as it had committed to and as we would have liked. We are enhancing our monitoring framework for the next period to ensure we get more granular information and will publish that quarterly and annually and on the dashboards.
When will that start?
Regarding the RC4 period, the funding period has already started. Our decision will be made next year, hopefully, by April. We are monitoring and reporting on an annual basis.
On the wastewater treatment plants. Where are the black spots in the country in terms of capacity?

Notwithstanding our role as a regulator, Uisce Éireann, the semi-State body tasked with the job, is as we speak spending billions. Our draft decision set out a capital programme for over five years of up to €16 billion that the Government has already approved. The Minister has approved that. Uisce Éireann is spending that money. It is upgrading all those treatment plants referred to by the Cathaoirleach. There is a list of those in the plan we have already published. It is up to Uisce Éireann to ensure there is security of supply of water to Dublin and everywhere else in the country. That is Uisce Éireann's job. When it gives us the business plan to say how it is going to achieve that, we approve the business plan. It is Uisce Éireann's responsibility to ensure-----
That is fine but let us say it is not doing the job. The Commission for Regulation of Utilities is the regulator. What can the regulator do about it other than having meetings?

We have incentive schemes and penalties. We penalise it where leakages occur. We set targets for leakages and for achieving projects and we can penalise it. In the past number of years, we have set targets for Uisce Éireann and penalised it.
How much in fines has Uisce Éireann paid to the regulator in recent years?
As part of the draft determination, we identified a €20 million fine in terms of leakage and an €11 million fine in terms as a financial penalty around billing.
Has Uisce Éireann paid those fines?
It is not that they are paid directly to us. It is accounted for in terms of its forward-looking framework for RC4.
That is not a fine at all then.

The nature of the regulatory framework means that we do not have powers of penalty for water. Uisce Éireann does not operate under a licence so it is quite a different regulatory framework to that for electricity and gas. Therefore, our regulatory tools are limited in terms of Uisce Éireann.

Technically, one can live without electricity but nobody can live without water. Dr. Kavanagh is telling me that the regulatory framework for water, which a person cannot live without, is very weak and mild compared to that for electricity and gas.
It is by virtue-----
Why is that the case? They are still the same and you cannot even find them.
Over the past ten years, the history of water-----
The local authorities-----

The local authorities have transitioned to Uisce Éireann in the main. There is still a legacy. It will be fully transitioned by 2026 or 2027. Domestic customers are subsidised by the Exchequer so the Cathaoirleach and I as domestic residential customers do not pay a water bill like every other country in Europe. The Exchequer funding is what subsidises Uisce Éireann. That does present a huge regulatory challenge in terms of us fining Uisce Éireann because, ultimately, all we are doing is reducing the Exchequer purse. From the point of view of Uisce Éireann, if we take €40 million or €50 million off it in fines, there is a challenge there insofar as that is €50 million or €20 million less it might have to spend on a water treatment plant. It is not like a shareholder company, private equity company or commercial company that would feel pain in its profit line if we as a regulator fine it so it is weaker than a normal regulatory environment. There is no doubt about that. As a regulator, regulating water in Ireland, given the Exchequer-funded model, is not as strong as it might be in many other jurisdictions.
Can I ask a blunt question? Why would Uisce Éireann pay any heed to the regulator then?

There is a lot of reporting it has to do. It has an independent board to which the executive team is held accountable. It is also accountable to the Minister, the Comptroller and Auditor General and the PAC.
Nobody can do anything about it.
It is working extremely hard and has made huge progress with our water infrastructure in the past ten years. There is no doubt about that.
From the regulator's point of view, the wastewater side is the general problem. I get grief in my constituency about wastewater treatment. The units were built ten years ago and are over capacity.

There are wastewater issues across the country but Uisce Éireann is making huge strides. For example, a huge wastewater treatment plant opened last year in Arklow. Arklow was a massive problem. That has now been resolved through a multimillion capital investment by Uisce Éireann so it is making progress but it is a challenge to make that progress as fast as is needed.
Surely the regulator must have an idea of when it thinks Uisce Éireann will be able to meet its requirements in terms of having adequate and safe wastewater treatment. Is it ten or 20 years?
Uisce Éireann is on record as saying it requires about €50 billion between now and 2050 to bring the water infrastructure in this State up to the standard required.
€50 billion. What is its proposed-----
That is up to 2050. It has €16 billion for the next five years.
I hate to think what commercial rates are going to be.
The investment is required.
I appreciate that but-----
The water and wastewater infrastructure in this State requires this investment urgently. There is no doubt about that.
I get that. We are in a difficult situation when it comes to Uisce Éireann.
It is challenging.
I will let Deputy Tóibín come in because he has not done previously. I will come back; I have some other questions.
He was with me in the Chamber discussing energy costs.
I am aware that there is a debate on a related topic in the Chamber as well.

Gabhaim buíochas leis na finnéithe ar fad as a bheith anseo. The International Energy Agency says that Ireland has the largest gap between wholesale and retail prices. We are told regularly that the reason why Ireland's electricity is so dear is because the nature of disparate housing, etc., and the infrastructure needed to bring it. Ireland has the largest gap between wholesale and retail prices so surely then it has the highest level of profiteering. Is that not the case?
I am happy to say there is no evidence of that.
There are valid underpinning reasons why we have more expensive electricity than other European jurisdictions-----
I do not want to be rude, but time-wise we will get cut off. If we leave wholesale completely aside, why is the gap between wholesale and retail the highest?

Part of that certainly is the work of suppliers relating to the size of the Irish market. In a very small market like ours, where prices on the wholesale side are more volatile, and in a smaller market in general, there are different hedging strategies that suppliers would have to take into account and take on board. In a smaller market, that tends to be more expensive because there is greater volatility on the wholesale side. In addition, in Ireland, as we have discussed previously, there are high levels of arrears at the moment but we have a level of disconnections that is in fact at about the same level as before Covid, so there has not been the level of disconnections that were there. It is not that we are seeking or that we want that, but there is a carrying cost for suppliers where they are not disconnecting people who are in arrears and in debt.

To finalise on this, we have stated in this session, and we will come back with more detail on it, that we are exercising two elements of our work plan next year. The first is a competition and competitiveness review of the retail market in Ireland. In the past, with the other Oireachtas joint committee we report to, we have articulated the different bits, including the wholesale price, we have looked at the network tariffs and we have talked about imperfections and capacity mechanism costs and the PSO, that is, other building blocks. This year coming, we are going back to look at competitiveness and competition in the retail space, and that is to look expressly at that gap between wholesale and retail for next year. Then, in parallel, we are going out for a call for evidence to look at arrears, debt and how we contend with those things in our retail market.

Is there any comparative analysis done in terms of other European markets and the level of profitability by players in the Irish market and the other levels? Let us say a retailer makes 10%. What is the average profit margin by an electricity company here per unit?

We do not have that data. I will pass to my colleague, Ms Karen Trant. Anecdotally, we understand that it is in the mid-single digits as regards profitability that the retail element of the suppliers would operate at. That is the kind of information we will seek. Separately, what we do have comparative data on, and again we can come back to the committee with this, is comparisons between Ireland's retail prices and European retail prices and, in particular, the Eurostat data, which is the European Commission data, which compares on the basis of purchasing power. It effectively looks at the cost of living in places like Bulgaria versus Ireland and it is the comparative cost of electricity in the jurisdictions-----
Does the CRU have the power to force a company to tell it its profit margin?

The companies produce regulated accounts. They also produce accounts for the CRO. We went through a supplier-of-last-resort event so we were able to drill down into granular detail into the companies' costs. We know from that exercise that we are talking about 3% to 5%. In the UK it is higher. It is probably in or around 7%. As Commissioner Gannon has said, we will do a review of that supplier cost piece next year. It was done in 2017. We will do it again and see where we are now because we are in a new normal.

If I may come back to the Deputy about the IEA piece, that wholesale comparative is the weighted cost of the European wholesale price. It is not our wholesale price. It is not Ireland's wholesale price. Our retail price bobs along with our wholesale price. That wholesale price is artificially deflated because Poland and other countries have a much bigger mixed portfolio of coal, gas, oil and so on, which gives a lower wholesale price. That is why it looks a bit at odds.

We look at the Eurostat data, and one area that is not maybe as publicly spoken about is power purchase ability, PPA, of individuals in Ireland. Our standard of living is much higher than other countries, such as Bulgaria, so when you add that into the Eurostat data it brings us down to about the 11th most expensive because of our wages and so on. PPA is probably a more accurate representation of where we are in terms of the costs of electricity and the cost of living.
I thank Ms Trant for that.

The price of electricity is tied to the highest priced unit provided on the day. Is that correct? Let us say wind provision could be quite cheap on a certain day but gas could be higher, but the price is tied to gas, and that pushes prices up, does it not? That is a Government policy decision.

No. The European Commission sets through regulation how the wholesale markets work. That then flows through to how we operate the wholesale market here. Effectively, there is a clearing price. The cheaper generators are bought first up to the last bit of volume that is needed to serve electricity in that moment and on that day, but it is that highest price point that then sets the amount the other generators would get. At the moment, the Deputy is right that gas tends to set that price more often than-----
That inflates the price to the customer.
It tends to clear the price. In terms of inflating the price-----
It is a higher price, obviously, to the customer.

It is higher, but once it is reflective and bought in a competitive market, which is how the wholesale market is set up, that people compete against one another, if gas sets the price, then it is the price of gas and supplying it that sets that price.
Is there not a logic then to decoupling the price of electricity from the highest provider of the day?

There were discussions in Europe in particular about this, and again Europe would set the regulation around the wholesale market, post Russia's invasion of Ukraine where prices in wholesale markets around Europe spiked significantly. Part of the consideration in Europe at the time was whether they would consider having two different markets or whether they would decouple gas from that. Europe did not pursue that option at that point in time, but that is not to say that over the coming years, particularly as renewables become an even greater part of the wholesale market, they would not look at that again. At the same time-----
But we have no choice as a country; we have to accept that particular European decision. Is that correct?
That rubric is set by the European Commission. However, it is important to note that even if that were done, we would still need gas as a backup-----
Did the Iberian Peninsula not decouple during that particular crisis and get permission to do so?
I think Spain and Portugal did. They made a decision to leave that process, as far as I understand.

I do not think they chose to decouple gas prices from their market. Where we chose a government credit intervention, which is at the back end, their intervention was in the market. We can come back with more detail on that, but that was not a redesign of their energy market.

Last year there were 30,000 blackouts in terms of electricity delivery, affecting 3 million people. When I saw that figure I was astounded by it. It was received through an FOI request by a journalist. I started to look at this. You go onto the British websites and all that information is readily available, but it is like pulling teeth out of ESB Networks. They are really reticent to deliver any information on that. It is quite a jaw-dropping figure and it does not include, to my understanding, Storm Éowyn. What kind of efforts can the CRU make to make sure that ESB Networks provides up-to-date information to citizens in terms of this in order that we can have a transparent process and that there is a penalty for that happening?
I will pass to my colleague Dr. Karen Kavanagh to talk about how we monitor and report on customer minutes lost and so on and then the incentives relating to same.

Customer outages are one of the things we monitor in terms of PR5 as part of the incentive programme, but in PR6 there is huge investment in the grid. There is up to €1 billion going in in terms of network resilience, upgrades and general network rehabilitation. In addition, in terms of the framework, we have performance incentives that are explicitly calling out customer minutes lost, customer outages and all those things that impact customer satisfaction. We will call that out and report on that quarterly as well as annually, and that feeds into the incentive framework, so I suppose-----
That is not in place at the moment. That is something that is going to happen, is it?

There is some reporting in there at the moment but, as we have tracked through the current process, we have identified some issues and sought additional enhanced monitoring in that regard. It is a recognised issue. It is probably something to be aware of that, as we invest heavily in the grid over the coming years, there will be some disruption. It is an area we really want to keep a focus on. It is not just storms but also some of the outages that have to happen as a result of the investment and the delivery of some of the bigger transmission infrastructure. That drives a certain amount of outages. We have enhanced modelling to see how our customers are being impacted directly. We will be reporting more frequently. It will probably be one of the things that feature on our dashboard.

Dr. Kavanagh says there is enhanced monitoring but, in fairness, in comparison with the information available to the public in Britain, we have far less information available. I also asked how much did it cost Electric Ireland to drop electricity provision for so many people so many times last year.

In terms of the incentive framework, ESB Networks was given a penalty of €7 million last year. Over the course of PR5, it incurred a penalty of over €57 million. That is all published in our annual documents. We publish the detail of all of this on an annual basis as part of the incentive report.
That is available on the CRU's website, is it?
I would be happy to forward it on.

I have one last question. It goes back to the Cathaoirleach's questions about water. My understanding is that the CRU's particular regulatory responsibility relates to the financial delivery model of the water systems in Ireland. Is Uisce Éireann living up to its responsibilities in those terms? In Meath, the delivery of water has been an absolute disaster in the last number of years. The town of Trim regularly has no water at all available at nighttime because of difficulties in the system. Ballivor had tankers of water being delivered for months and months because of the systems in the town breaking down. Restaurants and cafés regularly close in Enfield because there is no water available. I know there has been a massive increase in population in Meath, which demands massive infrastructural development, which is in play. The word "accountability" is very elastic. Somebody is accountable to somebody else but accountability means that there is a cost to an individual if the individual does not do his or her job. If there is no cost, there is no accountability in reality. What costs have ever been imposed on Uisce Éireann for the fall-off in delivery of service that happens so often in Meath?

I will go back to the point that Uisce Éireann is a semi-State body and is primarily funded by the Exchequer. Any profits it makes are reinvested in the network. Profits do not go to any shareholder or private equity company, as they would in other companies. It is a weak framework as regards Uisce Éireann suffering pain as a company and as a board as the result of profit being taken away. It is difficult to hold Uisce Éireann accountable. As the Deputy will know, in a normal commercial company, a board-----
There are bonuses, however. Uisce Éireann is a little bit famous for the bonuses it hands out on an annual basis. Are those bonuses not affected if the job of delivery-----

That is a matter for the board of Uisce Éireann and its remuneration committee. That semi-State company has all independent members and an independent chair that are non-executive. There is also an executive. The board is there to hold the executive to account. The board reports to the Minister and was appointed by the Minister. With regard to any bonuses for executives, unlike a normal private equity company, there are no long-term incentive plans or any of that sort of stuff. It is completely different.
To follow up on the point I made before, I would link in with Uisce Éireann-----

May I make a brief point? In terms of how we challenge Uisce Éireann on its operational costs and how the business is managed, as part of our RC4 determination, we are proposing to impose an efficiency challenge of 10%. We reviewed Uisce Éireann's costs in detail, looking back and looking forward, and benchmarked it against UK companies. We are proposing a 10% efficiency cut. That is where we impose that type of efficiency.

On the issues in Ratoath, one of the other parts of our role as an economic regulator relates to customer protection. We engaged with Uisce Éireann and with many of the councillors from Ratoath at the time those issues were being experienced to ensure that customers were getting the full benefit of all the provisions we set out in our handbook for non-domestic customers and some domestic customers. We engaged on that issue and followed up to make sure there was full compliance with the handbook.
To follow on from a point mentioned earlier, what is the breakdown of Uisce Éireann's income between Exchequer funding for domestic water supply and commercial income? What is the percentage?
It is approximately 80% to 20%.
Which is the 80%?
That is domestic. The other 20% is commercial.

Of a total of €1.6 billion, the Government subvention covers €1.2 billion and €230 million comes from commercial charges. On the gap, what was the third one? It is small. Either way, it was €1.2 billion of €1.6 billion.

We have mentioned people who are in arrears with their electricity bills. Does the CRU have any information as to the number of people who have pay-as-you-go meters? That is a way of preventing arrears building up. Are they more expensive for the consumer than a bill-pay arrangement and, if so, by how much? There is the extra cost of putting in the meter but at least you are getting paid upfront. The other ones, the likes of us, get our bills every two months and pay them in arrears. Will the witnesses talk me through that?

I will pass this question to my colleague Karen Trant. There is an existing system where people have pay-as-you-go meters. Separately, the smart meters are now enabled to allow people to pay as they go as well. Any supplier can offer that.
Mr. Gannon is correct. There is a mixed bag. There are hardship meters, which deal with arrears, and there are lifestyle choice meters, where people decide they are going to-----
For a lot of people in rented accommodation, the landlord will say-----

They are more expensive because the meter is a cost to the supplier. What the commissioner, Mr. Gannon, is alluding to is that the new smart meters have a functionality that allows for smart pay-as-you-go. Suppliers can offer that. It means the customer is not paying that additional fund for the meter. That is something that-----
Will Ms Trant send us a paper on this topic?
I will, of course. We have the numbers for pay-as-you-go but I do not have them in front of me.
The CRU seems to have a lot of knowledge about people in arrears but I would like to have something we could study.
We will provide that. One important thing is that, with the new smart meters that have come in, we have-----
Will the CRU give us the number that are out there?
We will do that, 100%. We have allowed this functionality so that people no longer need to get and pay for an additional meter. The smart meter allows you to avail of a product like that.
These are the new meters. They are only for new properties.
It is the new smart meters but they are in 2 million homes across the country now.
Everyone has a smart meter. There are about 2 million as a result of the meter replacement programme.
I have the answer. The gap was new connections. That is the €150 million I was missing.

In the notes it provided to us, the CRU mentioned that there will be €13.6 billion in expenditure by Uisce Éireann between 2025 and 2029. How much of that is capital versus current? If the witnesses do not have the figures to hand, they can send them on with the answers to the other questions.
Off the top of my head, it is about €8 billion. I will come back with a specific figure.
I ask the witnesses to come back with the figures because we hear these big figures but, if some of it relates to current expenditure, it is not investment.
I am sorry; what was the question?
In the briefing information we got, it said that there will be €13.6 billion in expenditure by Uisce Éireann between now and 2029.
It was looking for €10 billion. It was €4 billion and-----
With regard to what Uisce Éireann asked for, we proposed to give it €8.561 billion in capital expenditure and €5.018 billion for operational expenditure over that period.
That is 60:40. We hear this big figure but 40% of it relates to current expenditure on operating costs. It is not investment at all.
Uisce Éireann has a huge staff. The cost of running the business every year is huge.
It is not capital expenditure at all.
Operating costs account for €5 billion. It costs about €1 billion a year to run Uisce Éireann.
The other point to note on these numbers is that we have not yet received the submission in relation to the additional funding being provided under the national development plan.
The CRU will have that soon.
We will have to incorporate that into the price control for the period.
When the CRU gets that, which we hope will not take too long-----
We will have it shortly.

We will ask the CRU to send us a note. There are a couple of bits building up. I see a report in today's news that there is to be major development at Rosslare Europort, which will help with the construction of offshore energy facilities in the Irish Sea. Does the CRU have a view on that? Has it been involved in it? Surely that cannot happen without the CRU having some oversight. Is it relevant? I know it is a CIÉ facility but it is relevant to producing electricity. Where does the CRU come in?
It is not relevant to us in that it is a-----
It is not in the remit of the CRU.
It is not within our remit.

The Arklow wastewater treatment plant that is up and running was mentioned. How many regulators were involved in the process that the CRU dealt with? Who co-ordinates the regulators? We counted four here last week.
For a wastewater treatment plant?
For the Arklow plant.

A wastewater treatment plant is fully the responsibility of Uisce Éireann to deliver. Primarily it would have to go through planning with the local planning authority. In the case of Arklow that was Wicklow County Council. That would involve a huge planning process. The EPA would be involved in the licensing and in overseeing the expenditure from an efficiency point of view.
Who issues a foreshore licence?
That is MARA. I am not sure whether it was involved in an onshore wastewater treatment plant.
So, the CRU, the EPA, MARA and the local authority are involved. Did they ever all sit down together to discuss how we might do this efficiently?
There could be observations on file from other regulators as well.
Yes, there are other regulators as well.
I guess our role is-----

What we are looking at is trying to get all the systems we have developed in Ireland working together, rather than each one operating in its own silo. Arklow has been mentioned at two meetings in a row. I have not yet got the impression that the regulators met. I know they all have independent functions, but do they see how it makes life awkward? One regulator asks for something and another-----
Just-----
We are trying to see how those involved in the system work together.

I have been working in regulation for 20-odd years. I spent 11 years working in ComReg before this and ten years at the Department working on the broadband plan. We had an bord snip nua with Colm McCarthy, and I lived through that. Mr. McCarthy looked at all the regulators and how we could bring them all together. With ComReg, there was the Broadcasting Authority of Ireland at the time, and the question was asked as to why they could not work together. After a lot of reviews, and we remember that Mr. McCarthy cut the hell out of a lot of us back in the day, a lot of back-office stuff in regulators was put together, such as finance and IT functions, but they could not find synergies in the actual regulation. An bord snip nua could not put them together because it made no sense.
As I said at the beginning, we have 50 more regulators now than we had 30 years ago.

There is an important point to make on some of the things we see now. There is the renewable electricity directive, RED III. It does not care who has the role of getting these through the planning, consent and regulation processes. It states renewable energy projects of a certain size must happen within a two-year process and projects of another particular size must happen within one year. Measures like this coming from Europe already require us to work with other regulatory authorities, such as planning authorities, MARA and others, to see how we make sure a project can come through at sufficient pace. There are areas where we absolutely interact with other regulators. We have memoranda of understanding with them to make sure our teams are in lockstep and that projects can get through the processes.

There is a note in the statement about the intent to license 100 unlicensed LPG network operators. Do these 100 exist or are they new applicants? What kind of storage facilities do we have in Ireland for a one-month supply of oil for electricity or LPG?
Will the Cathaoirleach repeat his first question? Was it on safety?
There is a note that the CRU hopes to license 100 LPG network operators.

This is private LPG. It might be a small housing estate or a nursing home using a tank of gas at the side of the building. This is LPG gas. Instead of oil or something else, it is LPG. There are 100 of them.
Do they need licences?
They are unlicensed at the moment. From our perspective, there are safety issues about the networks. There is piping and everything else.
When was it decided to license these operators, particularly if they have been there for a good while?
We advised the Government, and there is legislation going through at present.
There is a gas safety Bill is coming through.
It is coming through, so the CRU has no authority-----
We have gas safety officer powers that we use at the moment. We have inspectors that inspect these sites to ensure they are safe.
Have any of them found to be deficient? If so, what does the CRU do in such circumstances?
We have found lots of issues with many of them.
What happened to them?

In the event that they are unsafe, we issue a cease-and-desist instruction that the gas cannot be used until the network owner, which is the owner of the building, remediates it and gets the requisite expert in, such as a gas installer.
Did this happen many times in the past year?
Several times, yes.
So the CRU wants to bring all of them up to standard.
Up to standard, yes. It is a critical piece of work.

That is good work. There is very good work behind that one little sentence. In terms of storage facilities for electricity, what kind of capacity do we have? I presume the CRU regulates the quality and safety of it.
In terms of energy safety we do not have a remit over oil. That is the National Oil Reserves Agency. It makes sure we have the 90 days' supply.
Another regulator. I am sorry, but this is a hot topic today because we have come across about six regulators so far.

It is slightly different. It is not a regulator. It makes sure that if oil is cut off, we have 90 days' supply on hand. It is the reserves agency. There is no equivalent for gas. There is a proposal for a strategic gas reserve for emergencies, and this would be the first real gas storage that Ireland would have. It will address the levels of gas that we have in case of interruption of supply, particularly with the interconnectors and that sort of thing. In terms of electricity, the storage technologies on the system at present are batteries in the main. We have Poulaphouca reservoir, which is pumped storage, but we do not have large-scale electricity storage on the island. However, we are bringing in things on the market that will give us this storage. The key reason for this is security of supply. It is also to ensure that when the wind blows but there is not a demand there for it, that we can store it for when the wind is not blowing and for peak times.
Is that battery storage?
By batteries and longer term batteries. This will help to secure supply.
As opposed to exporting it?
In tandem with interconnection, whereby we can export or import.
What if an operator wants to export or sell it to somebody for storage? Where the best price is will determine where it goes.

The wholesale market will determine this. People will generate energy and sell it into the wholesale market, and people will buy from that wholesale market. If someone across the interconnector wants to buy from Ireland because of the price it will be exported. Separately, if someone wants to charge their battery they would buy from the wholesale market and then choose when to sell it back in. It helps with the security of supply and decarbonisation, and it can also help to reduce costs by making sure we have the electrons when we need them.
Are there any further questions?

I have tons more questions, but one thing that jumps out at me is that the more people we meet and the more we discuss this, the more we see that the lines are so blurred. Something that also jumps out at me is the different remits in different areas. They are completely different with regard to gas and water. They are poles apart. There are similarities but my God, it is quite complex.
At this stage, we will bring an end to proceedings. I thank the witnesses for attending.
If we have individual issues with the CRU, who do we go to?
We have an Oireachtas email address that is often used by various people.
If all else fails, the clerk to the committee will get in contact.

Separately, as we said at the start and we do mean it, it is very important for us that people understand the work we do. We are across water, gas, electricity and energy safety. We could sit with the committee for days on each one of these, not because there are too many processes but because the brief this so broad. In terms of follow-up with the committee, and we have been given a few pieces of homework, we are very happy to do this. We are very happy to speak on our mandate. Sometimes we see different interpretations of reports and different interpretations of what we do and do not do and what others do. It is important that people see what we do, understand it and challenge us. We are accountable to the Houses of the Oireachtas and it is through these committees that we are challenged. That is also important.

I appreciate that. I ask that any information requested today be sent to us within two weeks. However, I am conscious that the witnesses have indicated some of the information will take a little longer. I ask that this be logged with the committee in order that we have an estimate of when we will receive that information. I ask that anything that can be sent to us within a fortnight is sent within this timeframe. There being no other business, I thank everyone for their attendance.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 5.49 p.m. until 3.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 17 December 2025.
